title: What would you like your smartphone to do in future years? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most is not about the phone as what it other tech it works with and what others let it do. I'd like it to: Let me pay for things.Let me see where my friends are.Let me get into things ( the subway, trains etc) ( virtual ticketing)Have a battery that lasts 3 days.Be able to type as fast as I talk via a speach type program.Send me suggestions based on what I am doing, begin to learn, like save battery by turning off wifi as I wonder around. Have a clear browsing experience, these intrusive online ads must stop.Allow me to control a lot of things around me, be my front door key, tell me what's in my fridge, be able to control my apartment temperature.

This year we have seen the different innovations from the mobile industry, such as the iPhoneX, and smartphone developments continue to impress us with their innovation and creativity (e.g. the rumoured Samsung S10 bezel-less design). What more can smartphones possibly showcase in the future? Here are some features that might continue or be included in the future lineups of smartphones.  Wireless - As more and more mobile devices include portable wireless charging, this will most likely increase and become a norm in the future. Wireless accessories, such as Apple’s wireless earphones called AirPods, will also most likely be a commercial possibility in the future. Thinner - Phones will continue to become thinner and lighter, thus making it more portable. How thin could phones get? A thinner hardware would mean lesser space for necessary computer processes such as microchips. Producing smaller but more capable chips would prove to become a challenge in the future. Battery - Batteries would most likely contain powerful and longer-lasting power. An idea presented in an article via Forbes on the future of smartphones, suggests that if phones are capable of receiving power over the air, batteries would not need to have extra storage power and can become smaller and leaner. Solar-powered smartphones are also a possibility. Transparent - With smartphones becoming more transparent, this removes a phone’s back side and allows both sides of the phone to function. This is possible as long as we manage to figure out how to put and fit all the necessary phone accessories like the battery and microchip while unseen. Aside from the difficulty of producing this kind of phone, questions on privacy would surface as the content you would be viewing would be seen through your phone. Smarter - How smart can smartphones get? We still don’t know how expansive software can get but as development for Artificial Intelligence and machine learning continues, it is possible for smartphones to be so smart that they can be able to predict queries or situations or already give out answers. Imagine yourself about to type a question, but before you could touch your screen, your smartphone has already predicted what it is and has already suggested your question on the search engine. That’s possibly how smart they can get, or more. It should have a battery-life of at least a week.It should understand normal spoken language. Current speech-recognition is HORRIBLE even in just transcribing to text -- nevermind understanding any of it. I'm talking simple stuff like: "When I leave the office, remind me to turn on the alarm!", "Please send my wife a text-message saying I'll be home around 4 today." Ideally, it should have strong AI and be the equivalent of a full-time highly-skilled personal secretary.It should be waterproof and able to survive physical abuse.It should encrypt all transmissions to reduce the risk of eavesdropping.It should talk to a lot more electronics around me -- for example the electronics in my house.

It should become invisible. I see no reason why someone should carry a heavy artificial object with them.It should be able to react to my emotions and cheer me up, if necessary.It should have no start screen, loading screen or other delays in time. I would like to talk to the person I want to talk to immediately.I would like it to react to language and gestures, not on the screen of the phone but with the world I am interacting with. If I am new to a city and show a friend a building, the phone should tell me which building it is. I would like it not to guide me towards the things I already enjoy ("the filter bubble") - but let me experience s. th. new each day and get me out of my comfort zone.

It should have a screen projector built in so I can setup presentations quickly.I should be able to create documents just like on a PC, without internet.It should have a battery life of at least 7-10 days.

Be able to charge itself from the radio waves in the air.  No need to charge up - EVER. Understand the priority of the call and the priority of the context I am in.  For example, do not ring when I am in an important meeting, unless it is someone very close or an ER or something like that.

Android phones should all at least have the same audio quality as iPhone does today, high end models should have dedicated amplifying chips.Cameras should focus on low light performance and higher dynamic range rather than pixel count.Screens should be made and calibrated to the sRGB standard like the iPhone 5.Waterproof without caps and plugs.Zero delay shutter, instanteneous camera start.High speed video, 120FPS or more.
Not die after several hours of active usage.
